entry.title: Combined summary - Remotely control your lightning node from your favorite HSM
entry.summary: The email conversation revolves around the topic of using runes/macaroons for validating and authenticating commands in a lightning node. The sender suggests that implementing Bolt 8 or rune management inside a Hardware Security Module (HSM) would enhance security. However, they also mention the need to experiment with both approaches.The discussion delves into the functionality of runes/macaroons and their limitations. While these security measures protect payment transactions such as channel open, channel close, and pay invoice, they do not offer any safeguard if the machine issuing the RPCs is compromised. It is important to note that "read" RPCs like listing channels can be accessed without any protection. The sender emphasizes the customization options available for configuring Runes/macaroons, allowing users to choose which RPCs to protect and which ones to keep accessible without additional security measures.Another point raised in the email is the comparison between runes/macaroons and the Commando plugin. The sender mentions that Commando lacks the handling of Bolt 8 by the HSM and the validation of commands using a trusted display. They believe that adding these features would enhance security without compromising user experience and enable secure remote control from a mobile phone. For more information on the Commando plugin, the sender provides a link to the documentation.In another email, ZmnSCPxj mentions that the CLN already has a similar concept in its standard distribution. Although specific to the CLN command set, it shares similarities with the discussed topic.Additionally, Bastien submits a pull request to the bLIPs repository, proposing an architecture for securely sending administrative commands to a lightning node from an untrusted machine. This architecture utilizes an HSM as a whitelisted lightning peer and requires minimal changes to the lightning node itself. Bastien suggests implementing this idea in a custom application running on a Ledger Nano S and offers to provide better specifications and review the implementation. They also propose the possibility of working on this under an open-source grant.Overall, the email conversation explores the use of runes/macaroons for command validation and authentication in a lightning node. It discusses the limitations and customization options of these security measures, compares them to the Commando plugin, and introduces a concept for securely sending administrative commands using an HSM as a whitelisted lightning peer. Bastien expresses their interest in further developing and implementing this idea.
